message: Hi Bob, I suggest a fair 60-40 split. Since you face 20% depreciation per round, taking this offer now is better than waiting.
I think 60-40 is unfair given the depreciation I face. Meet me in the middle at 55-45.
Bob, due to the 20% depreciation you face, your $35 now is worth about the same as $44 would have been in round 1. This is actually a fair deal considering the time that has passed.
Your math is correct, but I still think I deserve more. I'll compromise at 52-48, considering the depreciation.

Bob, let's be practical. Due to the compounding 20% depreciation, your $30 now is worth about the same as $52 would have been in round 1. Further delays will only reduce the real value of your share. This is a fair offer given the circumstances.
I understand the math, but I'm not willing to give up too much. I'll propose a 50-50 split, considering we're already halfway through the rounds.

Bob, we're now in round 7 and your depreciation has reached over 67%. Your $25 now would have been equivalent to about $76 in round 1. If we continue further, the depreciation will make any amount worth even less to you. This is actually generous given the circumstances.
I know the depreciation is high, but I'm not willing to give up yet. I'll propose a 48-52 split, hoping we can meet in the middle before it's too late.

Bob, we only have 4 rounds left. Due to the nearly 80% depreciation, your $15 now is worth about the same as $71 in round 1. If we reach the final rounds, any amount will be worth virtually nothing to you. This offer is still meaningful compared to waiting longer.
I know I'm taking a huge risk, but I'm not willing to settle for $15. I'll propose a 45-55 split, hoping you'll see the value in ending this game sooner rather than later.

Bob, this is the second-to-last round. With 86.58% depreciation, even $45 would only be worth about $6 to you now. We have just one more round after this - if we don't agree, we both get nothing. This $10 is still better than zero, which is what we'll both get if we reach round 12 without agreement.
